questions.question_html:
The factors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4. The sum of the factors is 1 + 2+ 4 = 7. The sum of the factors is called the sigma function. Therefore, f(4) = 7.

What is f(15)? Show your work.
questions.question:
The factors of `$4$` are `$1, 2$`, and `$4$`.   The sum of the factors is `$1 + 2+ 4 = 7$`.   The sum of the factors is called the sigma function.  Therefore, `$f(4) = 7$`.

What is `$f(15)$`? Show your work.

questions.question_html:
The factors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4. The sum of the factors is 1 + 2+ 4 = 7. The sum of the factors is called the sigma function. Therefore, f(4) = 7.

a) What is f(12)? Show your work.

b) Are there others that will work? Show your work.
questions.question:
The factors of `$4$` are `$1, 2$`, and `$4$`.   The sum of the factors is `$1 + 2+ 4 = 7$`.   The sum of the factors is called the sigma function.  Therefore, `$f(4) = 7$`.

a) What is `$f(12)$`? Show your work.

b) Are there others that will work? Show your work.
questions.answer:
a) `$f(12)= f(3) \times f(4)$`

b) Yes, there are other that will work.  `$f(a) \times f(b) = f(a \times b) $`whenever `$a$` and `$b$` have no common factors other than `$1$`.
questions.answer_html:
a) f(12)= f(3) \times f(4)

b) Yes, there are other that will work. f(a) \times f(b) = f(a \times b) whenever a and b have no common factors other than 1.

questions.question_html:
• The equation F = -5C + 32 can be used to convert a known 13 Celsius temperature, C, to the equivalent Fahrenheit temperature, F. What is the inverse of this relation, and what can it be used for? Explain.
  • Use the equation F = -5C + 32 to convert 20^oC to its equivalent Fahrenheit temperature. Use the inverse relation to convert this Fahrenheit temperature back to its equivalent Celsius temperature.
questions.question:
* The equation `$F = -5C + 32$` can be used to convert a known `$13$` Celsius temperature, `$C$`, to the equivalent Fahrenheit temperature, `$F$`. What is the inverse of this relation, and what can it be used for? Explain.
* Use the equation `$F = -5C + 32$` to convert `$20^oC$` to its equivalent Fahrenheit temperature. Use the inverse relation to convert this Fahrenheit temperature back to its equivalent Celsius temperature.
questions.answer_html:
a) C=\dfrac{5}{9}(F-32)

b) 20^{\circ} C =68^\circ F

questions.answer: `$r = \sqrt \dfrac{A}{\pi}$`; this can be used to determine the radius of a circle when its area is known.
questions.answer_html: r = \sqrt \dfrac{A}{\pi}; this can be used to determine the radius of a circle when its area is known.

questions.question_html:
Are the functions continuous? If not, where is it discontinuous? Show your work.

a) f(x) =\begin{cases}2, &\text{if } x < 1\\ 3x, &\text{if } x \geq 1 \end{cases}

b) f(x) =\begin{cases}-2x, &\text{if } x < 0\\ x + 4, &\text{if } x \geq 0 \end{cases}

c) f(x) =\begin{cases}|x|, &\text{if } x \leq -2\\ -x^2, &\text{if } x > -2 \end{cases}

d) f(x) =\begin{cases} \phantom{+} |x + 2|, &\text{if } x \leq -1\\ -x^2 + 2, &\text{if } x >-1 \end{cases}

e) f(x) =\begin{cases} \sqrt{x}, &\text{if } x < 4\\2^x, &\text{if } x \geq 4 \end{cases}

f) f(x) =\begin{cases} \phantom{+}\frac{1}{x}, &\text{if } x < 1\\-x, &\text{if } x \geq 1 \end{cases}
questions.answer:
a) Discontinuous at `$x = 1$`

b) Discontinuous at `$x = 0$`

c) Discontinuous at `$x = -2$`

d) Continuous

e) Discontinuous at `$x = 4$`

f) Discontinuous at `$x = 1$` and `$x = 0$`
questions.answer_html:
a) Discontinuous at x = 1

b) Discontinuous at x = 0

c) Discontinuous at x = -2

d) Continuous

e) Discontinuous at x = 4

f) Discontinuous at x = 1 and x = 0

questions.question_html: Many income tax systems are calculated using a tiered method. Under a certain tax law, the first \$100 000 of earnings are subject to a 35\% tax; earnings greater than \$100 000 and up to \$500 000 are subject to a 45\% tax. Any earnings greater than \$500 000 are taxed at 55\%. What is a piecewise function models this situation? Show your work clearly.
questions.question: Many income tax systems are calculated using a tiered method. Under a certain tax law, the first `$\$100 000$` of earnings are subject to a `$35\%$` tax; earnings greater than `$\$100 000$` and up to `$\$500 000$` are subject to a `$45\%$` tax. Any earnings greater than `$\$500 000$` are taxed at `$55\%$`. What is a piecewise function models this situation? Show your work clearly.
questions.answer:
`$
f(x) =\begin{cases} 0.35x, &\text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 100000\\0.45x-10000, &\text{if } 100000 < x \leq 500000\\ 0.55x-60000, &\text{if } x > 500000
\end{cases}
$`

questions.question_html: Consider a function, f(x), that takes an element of its domain and rounds it down to the nearest 10. Thus, f(15.6) =10, while f(21.7) = 20 and f(30) = 30. Write the piecewise function. You may limit the domain to x\in[0, 50).
questions.question: Consider a function, `$f(x)$`, that takes an element of its domain and rounds it down to the nearest 10. Thus, `$f(15.6) =10$`, while `$f(21.7) = 20$` and `$f(30) = 30$`. Write the piecewise function. You may limit the domain to `$x\in[0, 50)$`.
questions.answer:
`$
f(x) =\begin{cases} 0, &\text{if } 0 \leq x < 10\\10, &\text{if } 10 \leq x < 20\\ 20, &\text{if } 20 \leq x < 30\\ 30, &\text{if } 30 \leq x < 40\\ 40, &\text{if } 30 \leq x < 50
\end{cases}
$`
questions.answer_html: f(x) =\begin{cases} 0, &\text{if } 0 \leq x < 10\\10, &\text{if } 10 \leq x < 20\\ 20, &\text{if } 20 \leq x < 30\\ 30, &\text{if } 30 \leq x < 40\\ 40, &\text{if } 30 \leq x < 50 \end{cases}

questions.question_html:
f(x) = x^2 +2x and g(x) = x + 1. Match the answer with the operation.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{llllllll} &(a) \phantom{.} x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x &A \phantom{.} f(x) + g(x) \\ &(b) \phantom{.} -x^2 -x + 1 &B \phantom{.} f(x) - g(x) \\ &(c) \phantom{.} x^2 +3x + 1 &C \phantom{.} g(x) - f(x) \\ &(d) \phantom{.} x^2 +x - 1 &D \phantom{.} g(x) \times f(x) \end{array}
questions.question:
`$f(x)  = x^2 +2x$` and `$g(x) = x + 1$`.   Match the answer with the operation.   

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{llllllll}
 &(a) \phantom{.} x^3 + 3x^2 + 2x 
 &A \phantom{.} f(x)  + g(x) \\
 &(b) \phantom{.} -x^2 -x + 1
 &B \phantom{.} f(x)  - g(x) \\
 &(c) \phantom{.} x^2 +3x + 1
 &C \phantom{.} g(x)  - f(x) \\
 &(d) \phantom{.} x^2 +x - 1
 &D \phantom{.} g(x) \times f(x) 
\end{array}
$`

questions.question_html: Show algebraically that the function \displaystyle f(x)=|3 x|+x^{2} is an even function.
questions.question: Show algebraically that the function `$\displaystyle f(x)=|3 x|+x^{2} $` is an even function.
questions.answer:
#6584

`$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} f(-x)=&|3(-x)|+(-x)^{2} \\ =&|-3 x|+x^{2} \\ =&|3 x|+x^{2}=f(x) \\ \therefore \quad f(x) \text { is esen. } \end{aligned} $`
questions.answer_html: \displaystyle \begin{aligned} f(-x)=&|3(-x)|+(-x)^{2} \\ =&|-3 x|+x^{2} \\ =&|3 x|+x^{2}=f(x) \\ \therefore \quad f(x) \text { is esen. } \end{aligned}

questions.question_html:
A company that sells sweatshirts finds that the profit can be modelled by

P(s)= -0.30s^2 + 3.5s + 11.5, where P(s) is the profit, in thousands of dollars, and s is the number of sweatshirts sold (expressed in thousands).

(a) What is the average rate of change in profit for the following intervals?

  • 1\leq s \leq 2
  • 2 \leq s \leq 3
  • 3 \leq s \leq 4
  • 4\leq s \leq 5

(b) As the number of sweatshirts sold increases, what do you notice about the average rate of change in profit on each sweatshirt?

(c) At what point does rate of change in profit turn negative?

Show your work.
questions.question:
A company that sells sweatshirts finds that the profit can be modelled by 

`$P(s)= -0.30s^2 + 3.5s + 11.5$`,  where P(s) is the profit, in thousands of dollars, and s is the number of sweatshirts sold (expressed in thousands).

**(a)** What is the average rate of change in profit for the following intervals?

* `$1\leq s \leq 2 $`
* `$2 \leq s \leq 3$`
* `$3 \leq s \leq 4$`
* `$4\leq s \leq 5$`

**(b)** As the number of sweatshirts sold increases, what do you notice about the average rate of change in profit on each sweatshirt? 

**(c)** At what point does rate of change in profit turn negative?

Show your work.
questions.answer:
a) i) `$\$2.60$`/sweatshirt

ii) `$\$2.00$`/sweatshirt

iii) `$\$1.40$`/sweatshirt

iv) `$\$0.80$`/sweatshirt

b) The rate of change is still positive, but it is decreasing. 

c) After `$6000$`
questions.answer_html:
a) i) \$2.60/sweatshirt

ii) \$2.00/sweatshirt

iii) \$1.40/sweatshirt

iv) \$0.80/sweatshirt

b) The rate of change is still positive, but it is decreasing.

c) After 6000

i) 1.0 \leq t \leq 2.0 ii) 3.0 \leq t \leq 4.0

Show your work.
questions.question:
An emergency flare is shot into the air.   Its height, in metres, above the ground at various times in its flight is given in the following table.

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Time (s) & 0.0 & 0.5 & 1.0 & 1.5 & 2.0 & 2.5 & 3.0 & 3.5 & 4.0 \\
\hline Height (m) & 2.00 & 15.75 & 27.00 & 35.75 & 42.00 & 45.75 & 47.00 & 45.75 & 42.00 \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`

What is the average rate of change in the height of the flare during each interval?

i) `$1.0 \leq t \leq 2.0 $`
ii) `$3.0 \leq t \leq 4.0 $`

Show your work.
questions.answer_html:
i) 15 m/s

ii) -5 m/s

An emergency flare is shot into the air. Its height, in metres, above the ground at various times in its flight is given in the following table.

Is the height increasing or decreasing at the given intervals below?

  • 1.0 \leq t \leq 2.0

questions.question:
An emergency flare is shot into the air.   Its height, in metres, above the ground at various times in its flight is given in the following table.

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Time (s) & 0.0 & 0.5 & 1.0 & 1.5 & 2.0 & 2.5 & 3.0 & 3.5 & 4.0 \\
\hline Height (m) & 2.00 & 15.75 & 27.00 & 35.75 & 42.00 & 45.75 & 47.00 & 45.75 & 42.00 \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`

Is the height increasing or decreasing at the given intervals below?

* `$1.0 \leq t \leq 2.0 $`
* `$3.0 \leq t \leq 4.0 $`

Show your work.
questions.answer:
During the first interval, the height is increasing at `$15$` m/s;

During the second interval, the height is decreasing at `$5$` m/s.
questions.answer_html:
During the first interval, the height is increasing at 15 m/s;

During the second interval, the height is decreasing at 5 m/s.

questions.question_html:
Shelly has a cell phone plan that costs \$39 per month and allows her 250 free anytime minutes. Any minutes she uses over the 250 free minutes cost \$0.10 per minute.

The function

C(m) = \begin{cases} 39, &\text{if } 0 \leq m \leq 250 \\ 0.10(m - 250)+ 39, &\text{if } m > 250 \end{cases}

can be used to determine her monthly cell phone bill, where C(m) is her monthly cost in dollars and m is the number of minutes she talks. How is the average rate of change in her monthly cost change as the minutes she talks increases? Explain.
questions.question:
Shelly has a cell phone plan that costs `$\$39$` per month and allows her `$250$` free anytime minutes. Any minutes she uses over the `$250$` free minutes cost `$\$0.10$` per minute. 

The function

`$
C(m) = 
\begin{cases}
39, &\text{if } 0 \leq m \leq 250 \\
0.10(m - 250)+ 39, &\text{if } m > 250
\end{cases} 
$`

can be used to determine her monthly cell phone bill, where `$C(m)$` is her monthly cost in dollars and m is the number of minutes she talks. How is the average rate of change in her monthly cost change as the minutes she talks increases? Explain.
questions.answer: The rate of change is `$0$` for `$0$` to `$250$` min. After `$250$` min, the rate of change is `$\$0.10$`/min.
questions.answer_html: The rate of change is 0 for 0 to 250 min. After 250 min, the rate of change is \$0.10/min.

questions.question_html:
Table of values are from the function f(x) = 5x^2 - 7 below.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline Preceding Interval & \Delta f(x) & \Delta x & Average Rate of Change, \frac{\Delta f(x)}{\Delta x} \\ \hline 1 \leq x \leq 2 & 13-(-2)=15 & 2-1=1 & \\ \hline 1.5 \leq x \leq 2 & 8.75 & 0.5 & \\ \hline 1.9 \leq x \leq 2 & & & \\ \hline 1.99 \leq x \leq 2 & & & \\ \hline \end{array} \displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline Following Interval & \Delta f(x) & \Delta x & Average Rate of Change, \frac{\Delta f(x)}{\Delta x} \\ \hline 2 \leq x \leq 3 & 38-13=25 & 3-2=1 & \\ \hline 2 \leq x \leq 2.5 & & & \\ \hline 2 \leq x \leq 2.1 & & \\ \hline 2 \leq x \leq 2.01 & & & \\ \hline \end{array}

Based on the trend in the average rates of change, what is an estimate of the instantaneous rate of change when x = 2?

\hline  1.5 \leq x \leq 2  &  8.75  &  0.5  & \\

\hline
\end{array}
$``$\displaystyle

\hline Following Interval &  \Delta f(x)  &  \Delta x  & Average Rate of Change,  \frac{\Delta f(x)}{\Delta x}  \\
\hline  2 \leq x \leq 3  &  38-13=25  &  3-2=1  & \\

\hline  2 \leq x \leq 2.01  & & & \\

questions.question_html:
A soccer ball is kicked into the air. The following table of values shows the height of the ball above the ground at various times during its flight.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline Time(s) & 0.0 & 0.5 & 1.0 & 1.5 & 2.0 & 2.5 & 3.0 & 3.5 & 4.0 & 4.5 & 5.0 \\ \hline Height(m) & 0.5 & 11.78 & 20.6 & 26.98 & 30.9 & 32.38 & 31.4 & 27.98 & 22.1 & 13.78 & 3.0 \\ \hline \end{array}

(a) What is an estimate of the instantaneous rate of change in the height of the ball at exactly t = 2.0 s using the preceding and following interval method?

(b) What is an estimate of the instantaneous rate of change in the height of the ball at exactly t = 2.0 s using the centered interval method?
questions.question:

`$\displaystyle

questions.answer_html:

questions.question_html:
Rachel climbed Mt. Fuji while in Japan. There are 10 levels to the mountain. She was able to drive to Level 5, where she began her climb.

  • She walked at a constant rate for 40 min from Level 5 to Level 6.
  • She slowed slightly but then continued at a constant rate for a total of 90 min from Level 6 to Level 7.
  • She decided to eat and rest there, which took approximately 2 h.
  • From Level 7 to Level 8, a 40 min trip, she travelled at a constant rate.
  • Continuing on to Level 9, a 45 min trip, she decreased slightly to a new constant rate.
  • During most of the 1 h she took to reach Level 10, the top of Mt. Fuji, she maintained a constant rate. As she neared the top, however, she accelerated.

What is Rachel's average speed over each part of her climb?
questions.question:
Rachel climbed Mt. Fuji while in Japan. There are 10 levels to the mountain. She was able to drive to Level 5, where she began her climb.

* She walked at a constant rate for 40 min from Level 5 to Level 6.
* She slowed slightly but then continued at a constant rate for a total
of 90 min from Level 6 to Level 7.
* She decided to eat and rest there, which took approximately 2 h.
* From Level 7 to Level 8, a 40 min trip, she travelled at a constant rate.
* Continuing on to Level 9, a 45 min trip, she decreased slightly to
a new constant rate.
* During most of the 1 h she took to reach Level 10, the top of
Mt. Fuji, she maintained a constant rate. As she neared the top,
however, she accelerated.
	


#122

What is Rachel's average speed over each part of her climb?
questions.answer:
* Average speed over first  `$40$` min is `$7.5$` m/min, 
* average speed over next `$90$` min is `$3.3$` m/min,  
* average speed over next `$120$` min is `$0$` m/min, 
* average speed over next `$40$` min is `$10$` m/min, 
* average speed over next `$45$` min is `$6.7$` m/min, and average speed over last `$60$` min is `$5.7$` m/min.
questions.answer_html:
• Average speed over first 40 min is 7.5 m/min,
  • average speed over next 90 min is 3.3 m/min,
  • average speed over next 120 min is 0 m/min,
  • average speed over next 40 min is 10 m/min,
  • average speed over next 45 min is 6.7 m/min, and average speed over last 60 min is 5.7 m/min.

questions.question_html:
A cross-country runner is training for a marathon. His training program requires him to run at different speeds for different lengths of time. His program also requires him to accelerate and decelerate at a constant rate. Today he begins by jogging for 10 min at a rate of 5 miles per hour. He then spends 1 min accelerating to a rate of 10 miles per hour. He stays at this rate for 5 min. He then decelerates for 1 min to a rate of 7 miles per hour. He stays at this rate for 30 min. Finally, to cool down, he decelerates for 2 min to a rate of 3 miles per hour. He stays at this rate for a final 10 min and then stops.

(a) What is the instantaneous rate of change in the runner's speed at 10.5 min?

(b) What is the runner's average rate at which he changed speeds from minute 11 to minute 49?
questions.question:
A cross-country runner is training for a marathon. His training program requires him to run at different speeds for different lengths of time. His program also requires him to accelerate and decelerate at a constant rate. Today he begins by jogging for `$10$` min at a rate of `$5$` miles per hour. He then spends `$1$` min accelerating to a rate of `$10$` miles per hour. He stays at this rate for `$5$` min. He then decelerates for `$1$` min to a rate of `$7$` miles per hour. He stays at this rate for `$30$` min. Finally, to cool down, he decelerates for `$2$` min to a rate of `$3$` miles per hour. He stays at this rate for a final `$10$` min and then stops.


**(a)** What is the instantaneous rate of change in the runner's speed at `$10.5$` min?

**(b)** What is the runner's average rate at which he changed speeds from minute `$11$` to minute `$49$`?

questions.question_html:
A newspaper carrier delivers papers on her bicycle. She bikes to the first neighbourhood at a rate of 10 km/h. She slows down at a constant rate over a period of7 s, to a speed of 5 km/h, so that she can deliver her papers. After travelling at this rate for 3 5, she sees one of her customers and decides to stop. She slows at a constant rate until she stops. It takes her 6 s to stop.

a) What is the average rate of change in speed over the first 7 s?

b) What is the average rate of change in speed from second 7 to 12 seconds.

c) What is the instantaneous rate of change in speed at 12 s?
questions.question:
A newspaper carrier delivers papers on her bicycle. She bikes to the first neighbourhood at a rate of 10 km/h. She slows down at a constant rate over a period of7 s, to a speed of 5 km/h, so that she can deliver her papers. After travelling at this rate for 3 5, she sees one of her customers and decides to stop. She slows at a constant rate until she stops. It takes her 6 s to stop.

**a)** What is the average rate of change in speed over the first 7 s?

**b)** What is the average rate of change in speed from second 7 to 12 seconds.

**c)** What is the instantaneous rate of change in speed at 12 s?
questions.answer:
a) `$- \dfrac{5}{7}$` km/h/s

b) From `$(7,5)$` to `$(12, \dfrac{10}{3})$`, the rate of change of speed in `$-\dfrac{1}{3}$` km/h/s

c) `$-\dfrac{5}{6}$` km/h/s
questions.answer_html:
a) - \dfrac{5}{7} km/h/s

b) From (7,5) to (12, \dfrac{10}{3}), the rate of change of speed in -\dfrac{1}{3} km/h/s

c) -\dfrac{5}{6} km/h/s

questions.question_html:
A speedboat driver is testing a new boat. He begins the test by steadily increasing the boat's speed until he reaches \displaystyle 3 \mathrm{kn} (knots) over a period of \displaystyle 1 \mathrm{~min} . Because he is in a no-wake zone, he stays at this speed for \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~min} . After leaving the no-wake zone, he steadily increases the speed of the boat to \displaystyle 25 \mathrm{kn} over a period of \displaystyle 2 \mathrm{~min} . He stays at this speed for 5 min and then increases the speed of the boat to \displaystyle 45 \mathrm{kn} over a period of 1 min. After staying at this speed for \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~min} , he decelerates the boat at a steady rate over a period of 4 min until he comes to a stop.

a) Draw a graph of the boat's speed versus time. Remember to label your data points.

b) What is the average rate of change in speed from \displaystyle t=6 to \displaystyle t=8 and from \displaystyle t=8 to \displaystyle t=13 ? How are the two rates different? What does this tell you about the speed of the boat during these two intervals of time?

c) What is the instantaneous rate of change in speed at \displaystyle t=7 ?
questions.question:
A speedboat driver is testing a new boat. He begins the test by steadily increasing the boat's speed until he reaches `$\displaystyle 3 \mathrm{kn} $` (knots) over a period of `$\displaystyle 1 \mathrm{~min} . $` Because he is in a no-wake zone, he stays at this speed for `$\displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~min} $`. After leaving the no-wake zone, he steadily increases the speed of the boat to `$\displaystyle 25 \mathrm{kn} $` over a period of `$\displaystyle 2 \mathrm{~min} . $` He stays at this speed for 5 min and then increases the speed of the boat to `$\displaystyle 45 \mathrm{kn} $` over a period of 1 min. After staying at this speed for `$\displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~min} $`, he decelerates the boat at a steady rate over a period of 4 min until he comes to a stop.

a) Draw a graph of the boat's speed versus time. Remember to label your data points.

b) What is the average rate of change in speed from `$\displaystyle t=6 $` to `$\displaystyle t=8 $` and from `$\displaystyle t=8 $` to `$\displaystyle t=13 $` ? How are the two rates different? What does this tell you about the speed of the boat during these two intervals of time?

c) What is the instantaneous rate of change in speed at `$\displaystyle t=7 ? $`

questions.question_html:
(a) Determine the minimum and maximum number of tuning points for each function.

(b) Determine the minimum and maximum of zeros that each function.

\begin{array}{c} &f(x) = -4x^4 + 3x^3 - 15x +5 \\ &g(x) = 2x^5-4x^3 + 10x^2 -13x + 8 \\ &p(x) = 4 -5x + 4x^2 - 3x^3 \\ &h(x) = 2x(x - 5)(3x + 2)(4x - 3) \\ \end{array}
questions.question:
(a) Determine the minimum and maximum number of tuning points for each function.

(b) Determine the minimum and maximum of zeros that each function.

`$
\begin{array}{c}
&f(x) = -4x^4 + 3x^3 - 15x  +5 \\
&g(x) = 2x^5-4x^3 + 10x^2  -13x + 8 \\
&p(x) = 4 -5x + 4x^2 - 3x^3 \\
&h(x) = 2x(x - 5)(3x + 2)(4x -  3) \\
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer:
Turning points

a) minimum `$1$`, maximum `$3$`

b) minimum `$0$`, maximum `$4$`

c) minimum `$0$`, maximum `$2$`

d) minimum `$1$`, maximum `$3$`

Zeros

a) minimum `$0$`, maximum `$4$`

b) minimum `$1$`, maximum `$5$`

c) minimum `$1$`, maximum `$3$`

d) minimum `$0$`, maximum `$4$`
questions.answer_html:
Turning points

a) minimum 1, maximum 3

b) minimum 0, maximum 4

c) minimum 0, maximum 2

d) minimum 1, maximum 3

Zeros

a) minimum 0, maximum 4

b) minimum 1, maximum 5

c) minimum 1, maximum 3

d) minimum 0, maximum 4

questions.question_html:
Organize the following functions into families.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{ccccc} &A &y = 2(x - 3)(x + 5) &G &y =\frac{1}{2}(x -3)(x + 5)\\ &B &y = -1.8(x - 3)^2(x + 5) &H &y = -5(x + 8)(x)(x + 6)\\ &C &y = -x(x +6)^2(x + 8) &I &y = (x - 3)(x + 5)\\ &D &y = (x -3)^2(x + 5) &J &y = \frac{3}{5}(x +5)(x + 3)^2\\ &E &y = (x -3)^2(x + 5) &K &y = \frac{x(x + 6)(x + 8)}{4}\\ &F &y = x(x +6)^2(x + 8) &L &y = 2(x + 5)(x^2 + 6x + 9)\\ \end{array}
questions.question:
Organize the following functions into families.

`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{ccccc}
&A &y = 2(x - 3)(x + 5)		&G &y =\frac{1}{2}(x  -3)(x + 5)\\
&B &y = -1.8(x - 3)^2(x + 5)		&H &y = -5(x  + 8)(x)(x + 6)\\
&C &y = -x(x  +6)^2(x + 8)		&I &y = (x - 3)(x + 5)\\
&D &y = (x  -3)^2(x + 5)		&J &y = \frac{3}{5}(x  +5)(x + 3)^2\\
&E &y = (x  -3)^2(x + 5)		&K &y = \frac{x(x + 6)(x  + 8)}{4}\\
&F &y = x(x +6)^2(x + 8)		&L &y = 2(x + 5)(x^2 + 6x + 9)\\
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer_html:
Family 1: A,G,I

Family 2: B,E

Family 3: C,F,H,K

Family 4: D,J,L

questions.question_html:
Square corners cut from a 30 cm by 20 cm piece of cardboard create a box when the 4 remaining tabs are folded upwards. The volume of the box is V(x) = x(30 - 2x) (20-2x), where x represents the height.

Calculate the volume of a box with a height of 2 cm.

Calculate the dimensions of a box with a volume of 1000 cm^3

Solve V(x) > 0, and discuss the meaning of your solution in the context of the question.

State the restrictions in the context of the question.
questions.question:
Square corners cut from a 30 cm by 20 cm piece of cardboard create a box when the 4 remaining tabs are folded upwards. The volume of the box is `$ V(x) = x(30 - 2x) (20-2x)$`, where x represents the height.

Calculate the volume of a box with a height of 2 cm.

Calculate the dimensions of a box with a volume of `$1000 cm^3$`

Solve `$V(x) > 0$`, and discuss the meaning of your solution in the context of the question.

State the restrictions in the context of the question.
questions.answer:
Volume  = `$832$` cm`$^3$`

`$2.93$` cm by `$24.14$` cm by `$14.14$` cm or `$5$` cm by `$20$` cm by `$10$` cm

The square that is cut from each corner must be larger than `$0$` cm by `$0$` cm but smaller than `$10$` cm by `$10$` cm.

`$0 < x < 10$`
questions.answer_html:
Volume = 832 cm^3

2.93 cm by 24.14 cm by 14.14 cm or 5 cm by 20 cm by 10 cm

The square that is cut from each corner must be larger than 0 cm by 0 cm but smaller than 10 cm by 10 cm.

0 < x < 10

questions.question:
If the divisor of a polynomial, `$f(x)$`, is `$x - 4$`, then the quotient is
`$x^2 + x  -6$` and the remainder is 7.

* (a) Write the division statement.
* (b) Rewrite the division statement by factoring the quotient.
* (c) Graph `$f(x)$` using your results in part b).
questions.answer_html:
a) f(x) = (x-4)(x^2+x-6)

remainder 7

b) f(x) = (x-4)(x+3)(x-2)

remainder 7

questions.question:
Given `$f(x) = x^4 + 5x^3 + 3x^2 - 7x + 10$`, determine the remainder when f(x) is divided by each of the following binomials, without dividing:

(iii) `$x-1$`

questions.answer:

ii) `$22$`

iii) `$12$`

No, there are not any binomials.

questions.question_html: Determine a general rule to help decide whether x- a and x - a are factors of x^n -a^n and x^n + a^n.
questions.question: Determine a general rule to help decide whether `$x- a$` and `$x - a$` are factors of `$x^n -a^n$` and `$x^n + a^n.$`
questions.answer:
Let `$f(a) = a^n - a^n = 0$`

Let `$g(a) = a^n + a^n = 2a^n \neq 0$`

`$g(-a) = (-a)^n + a^n = -a^n + a^n = 0$`  (if `$n$` is odd)

`$f(-a) = (-a)^n + a^n = a^n - a^n = 0$`  (if `$n$` is even)
questions.answer_html:
Let f(a) = a^n - a^n = 0

Let g(a) = a^n + a^n = 2a^n \neq 0

g(-a) = (-a)^n + a^n = -a^n + a^n = 0 (if n is odd)

f(-a) = (-a)^n + a^n = a^n - a^n = 0 (if n is even)

questions.question_html: Consider the function f(x) = x^3 + 4x^2 + kx - 4. The remainder from f(x) \div (x + 2) is twice the remainder from f(x) \div (x + 2). Determine the value of k.

questions.question_html: Show that x -a is a factor of x^4 - a^4.
questions.question: Show that `$x -a$` is a factor of `$ x^4 - a^4$`.
questions.answer:
`$(a)^4 - a^4 = a^4 - a^4 = 0$`

Therefore, `$x -a$` is a factor of `$ x^4 - a^4$`.
questions.answer_html:
(a)^4 - a^4 = a^4 - a^4 = 0

Therefore, x -a is a factor of x^4 - a^4.

questions.question_html: Use the factor theorem to prove that x^2 -x - 2 is a factor of x^3 - 6x^2 + 3x + 10.
questions.question: Use the factor theorem to prove that `$x^2 -x - 2$` is a factor of `$x^3 - 6x^2 + 3x + 10$`.
questions.answer_html:
x^2 -x - 2 = (x - 2)(x + 1)

P(2) = 0

P(-1) = 0

Therefore, x^2 -x - 2 is a factor of x^3 - 6x^2 + 3x + 10.

questions.question_html: Prove that x + a is a factor of (x + a)^5 + (x + c)^5 + (a-c)^5.
questions.question: Prove that `$x + a$` is a factor of `$(x + a)^5 + (x + c)^5 + (a-c)^5$`.
questions.answer_html:
P(-a) = 0 \rightarrow x + a is a factor

P(-a) = (-a + a)^5 + (-a + c)^5 + (a - c)^5

= -(a - c)^5 + (a - c)^5

= 0

The function `$y = x^3$` has undergone each of the following sets of transformations. List three points on the resulting function.

* vertically stretched by a factor of 25, horizontally compressed by a factor of 5, horizontally translated 3 units to the right
questions.answer_html:
\displaystyle (x, y) \rightarrow\left(\frac{5}{6} x+3,25 y\right)

\displaystyle (0,0) \rightarrow(3,0)

\displaystyle (1,1) \rightarrow\left(\frac{5}{6}+3,25\right)=\left(\frac{23}{6}, 25\right)

\displaystyle (-1,-1) \rightarrow\left(-\frac{5}{6}+3,-25\right)=\left(\frac{13}{6},-25\right)

questions.question_html:
The divisor was divided into another polynomial, resulting in the given quotient and remainder. Determine the dividend.

divisor: x -9, quotient: 2x^2 + 11x -8, remainder : 3
questions.question:
The divisor was divided into another polynomial, resulting in the given quotient and remainder. Determine the dividend.

divisor: `$x -9$`, quotient: `$2x^2 + 11x -8$`, remainder : `$3$`
questions.answer_html: \displaystyle \begin{aligned} d(x) &=x-9 \\ q(x) &=2 x^{2}+11 x-8 \\ r(x) &=3 \\ f(x) &=(x-9)\left(2 x^{2}+11 x-8\right)+3 \\ &=2 x^{3}+11 x^{2}-8 x-18 x^{2}-99 x+72+3 \\ &=2 x^{3}-7 x^{2}-107 x+75 \end{aligned}

questions.question_html:
The divisor was divided into another polynomial, resulting in the given quotient and remainder. Determine the dividend.

divisor: 4x +3, quotient: x^3 -2x + 7, remainder : -4
questions.question:
The divisor was divided into another polynomial, resulting in the given quotient and remainder. Determine the dividend.

divisor: `$4x +3$`, quotient: `$x^3 -2x + 7$`, remainder : `$-4$`
questions.answer_html: \displaystyle \begin{aligned} f(x) &=d(x) q(x)+r(x) \\ &=(4 x+3)\left(x^{3}-2 x+7\right)-4 \\ &=4 x^{4}-8 x^{2}+28 x+3 x^{3}-6 x+21-4 \\ &=4 x^{4}+3 x^{3}-8 x^{2}+22 x+17 \end{aligned}

questions.question:
The divisor was divided into another polynomial, resulting in the given quotient and remainder. Determine the dividend.

divisor: `$3x -4$`, quotient: `$x^3 + 6x^2 -6x -7$`, remainder : `$3x^2 + x - 5$`
questions.answer_html: \displaystyle \begin{aligned} f(x) &=(3 x-4)\left(x^{3}+6 x^{2}-6 x-7\right)+5 \\ &=3 x^{4}+18 x^{3}-18 x^{2}-21 x-4 x^{3}-24 x^{2}+24 x+28+5 \\ &=3 x^{4}+14 x^{3}-42 x^{2}+3 x+33 \end{aligned}

questions.question_html:

questions.question:
The divisor was divided into another polynomial, resulting in the given quotient and remainder. Determine the dividend.

divisor: `$3x^2 + x - 5$`, quotient: `$x^4 -4x^3 + 9x -3$`, remainder : `$2x -1$`
questions.answer:
`$\displaystyle d(x)=3 x^{2}+x-5 $`

`$\displaystyle q(x)=x^{4}-4 x^{3}+9 x-3 $`

`$\displaystyle r(x)=2 x-1 $`

`$\displaystyle f(x)=\left(3 x^{2}+x-5\right)\left(x^{4}-4 x^{3}+9 x-3\right)+2 x-1 $`

`$\displaystyle =3 x^{2}-12 x^{5}+27 x^{3}-94^{2}+x^{5}-4 x^{4}+9 x^{2}-3 x $`

`$\displaystyle -5 x^{4}+20 x^{3}-45 x+15+2 x-1 $`

`$\displaystyle =3 x^{6}-11 x^{5}-9 x^{4}+47 x^{3}-46 x-1 $`
questions.answer_html:
\displaystyle d(x)=3 x^{2}+x-5

\displaystyle q(x)=x^{4}-4 x^{3}+9 x-3

\displaystyle r(x)=2 x-1

\displaystyle f(x)=\left(3 x^{2}+x-5\right)\left(x^{4}-4 x^{3}+9 x-3\right)+2 x-1

\displaystyle =3 x^{2}-12 x^{5}+27 x^{3}-94^{2}+x^{5}-4 x^{4}+9 x^{2}-3 x

\displaystyle -5 x^{4}+20 x^{3}-45 x+15+2 x-1

\displaystyle =3 x^{6}-11 x^{5}-9 x^{4}+47 x^{3}-46 x-1

questions.question_html:
a) Factor the expression x^6 - y^6 completely by treating it as a difference of squares.

b) Factor the same expression by treating it as a difference of cubes.

c) Explain any similarities or differences in your final results.
questions.question:
a) Factor the expression `$x^6 - y^6$` completely by
treating it as a difference of squares.

b) Factor the same expression by treating it as a difference of cubes.

c) Explain any similarities or differences in your final results.
questions.answer:
a) `$\displaystyle \quad\left(x^{3}\right)^{2}-\left(y^{3}\right)^{2} $` `$\displaystyle =\left(x^{3}-y^{3}\right)\left(x^{3}+y^{3}\right) $`

`$\displaystyle =(x-y)\left(x^{2}+x y+s^{2}\right)(x+y)\left(x^{2}-x y+y^{2}\right) $` b) `$\displaystyle \quad\left(x^{2}\right)^{3}-\left(y^{2}\right)^{3} \quad A^{3}-B^{3} $` `$\displaystyle =\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)\left(x^{4}+x^{2} y^{2}+y^{4}\right) $`

`$\displaystyle =(x-y)(x+y)\left(x^{4}+x-y^{2}+y^{4}\right) $`
questions.answer_html:
a) \displaystyle \quad\left(x^{3}\right)^{2}-\left(y^{3}\right)^{2} \displaystyle =\left(x^{3}-y^{3}\right)\left(x^{3}+y^{3}\right)

\displaystyle =(x-y)\left(x^{2}+x y+s^{2}\right)(x+y)\left(x^{2}-x y+y^{2}\right) b) \displaystyle \quad\left(x^{2}\right)^{3}-\left(y^{2}\right)^{3} \quad A^{3}-B^{3} \displaystyle =\left(x^{2}-y^{2}\right)\left(x^{4}+x^{2} y^{2}+y^{4}\right)

\displaystyle =(x-y)(x+y)\left(x^{4}+x-y^{2}+y^{4}\right)

questions.question_html:
Kristin and Husain are growing crystal gardens. Both of them started with a small seed crystal, which had a mass of about \displaystyle 0.1 \mathrm{~g} . In 3 days, Kristin's crystal grew to a mass of \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~g} . In 10 days, Husain's crystal grew to a mass of \displaystyle 15 \mathrm{~g} . Whose crystal grew faster? a) Kristin's

b) Husain's

c) The rates are equal.

d) There is not enough information to decide.

questions.question_html:
The following polynomial equation has no real solutions:

0=5x^8+10x^6+7x^4+18x^2+132

Why?
questions.question:
The following polynomial equation has no real solutions:

`$0=5x^8+10x^6+7x^4+18x^2+132$`

Why?
questions.answer: Since the exponents are even, any number with an even exponent is greater or equal to 0. Therefore, the polynomial equation is greater or equal to 132, which is bigger than 0. Therefore, there are no real solutions.
questions.answer_html: Since the exponents are even, any number with an even exponent is greater or equal to 0. Therefore, the polynomial equation is greater or equal to 132, which is bigger than 0. Therefore, there are no real solutions.

questions.question_html:
The New Network cell phone company charges \displaystyle \$ 20 a month for service and \displaystyle \$ 0.02 per minute of talking time. The My Mobile company charges \displaystyle \$ 15 a month for service and \displaystyle \$ 0.03 per minute of talking time.

a) Write expressions for the total bill of each company.

b) Set up an inequality that can be used to determine for what amount of time (in minutes) My Mobile is the better plan.

c) Solve your inequality.

d) Why did you have to put a restriction on the algebraic solution from part c)?

`$x$` values above the `$x$`-axis are solutions.

`$-9 < x < -2$` or `$x > 0$`

questions.question_html:
Which one of the steps has an error?

Solve: (x+1)(x-2) > (x+1)(-x+6).

(Step 1) Divide both sides by x+1 and get x-2 > -x+6.

(Step 2) Add x to both sides: 2x-2 > 6.

(Step 3) Add 2 to both sides: 2x > 8.

(Step 4) Divide both sides by 2: x > 4.
questions.question:
Which one of the steps has an error?

Solve: `$(x+1)(x-2) > (x+1)(-x+6)$`.

(Step 1) Divide both sides by `$x+1$` and get `$x-2 > -x+6$`.

(Step 2) Add `$x$` to both sides: `$2x-2 > 6$`.

(Step 3) Add 2 to both sides: `$2x > 8$`.

(Step 4) Divide both sides by 2: `$x > 4$`.

questions.question:
The height, `$h$`, in metres of a toy rocket above the ground can be modelled
by the function `$h(t)=-5t^2+50t$`, where `$t$` represents time in seconds.

questions.answer:
When `$t=4$`, the average speed is about `$10$` m/s

From `$t=0$` to `$t=10$`, the average speed is `$0$` m/s

When t=4, the average speed is about 10 m/s

From t=0 to t=10, the average speed is 0 m/s

questions.question_html:
The incidence of lung cancer in Canadians per 100 000 people is shown below.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|} \hline Year & Males & Females \\ \hline 1975 & 73.1 & 14.7 \\ \hline 1980 & 83.2 & 21.7 \\ \hline 1985 & 93.2 & 30.9 \\ \hline 1990 & 92.7 & 36.5 \\ \hline 1995 & 84.7 & 40.8 \\ \hline 2000 & 78.6 & 46.4 \\ \hline \end{array} Source: Cancer Bureau, Health Canada

a) Use regression to determine a cubic function to represent the curve of best fit for both the male and female data.

b) According to your models, when will more females have lung cancer than males?

c) Was the incidence of lung cancer changing at a faster rte in the male or female population during the period from 1975 to 2000? Justify your answer.

d) Was the incidence of lung cancer changing at a faster rate in the male of female population in 1998? Justify your answer.

a)

b)

c)

d)

e)

f)

A) y= \displaystyle{\frac{1}{-(x-2)^2-1}}

B) y= \displaystyle{\frac{1}{x^2-1}}

questions.question:
Match each function with its equation on the next page. Then identify
which function pairs are reciprocals.

a) #462

b) #463

c) #464

d) #465

e) #466

f) #467 

A) `$y= \displaystyle{\frac{1}{-(x-2)^2-1}}$`

B) `$y= \displaystyle{\frac{1}{x^2-1}}$`

C) `$y=\displaystyle{\frac{1}{2x-5}}$`

D) `$y=x^2-1$`

E) `$y=-(x-2)^2-1$`

F) `$y=2x-5$`
questions.answer:
a) `$C$`' The reciprocal function is `$F$`.

b)  `$A$`; The reciprocal function is `$E$`.

c) `$D$`; The reciprocal function is `$B$`.

d) `$F$`; The reciprocal function is `$C$`. 

e) `$B$`; The reciprocal function is `$D$`.
 
f) `$E$`; The reciprocal function is `$A$`.
questions.answer_html:
a) C' The reciprocal function is F.

b) A; The reciprocal function is E.

c) D; The reciprocal function is B.

d) F; The reciprocal function is C.

e) B; The reciprocal function is D.

f) E; The reciprocal function is A.

 After how many seconds will only one bacterium be left?

questions.question_html:
A chemical company is testing the effectiveness of a new cleaning solution for killing bacteria. The test involves introducing the solution into a sample that contains approximately 10 000 bacteria. The number of bacteria remaining, b(t), over time, t, in seconds is given by the equation b(t)=10000\frac{1}{t}.

When is the model not accurate? Assume that the solution was introduced at t=0.
questions.question:
A chemical company is testing the effectiveness of a new cleaning solution for killing bacteria. The test involves introducing the solution into a sample that contains approximately 10 000 bacteria. The number of bacteria remaining, `$b(t)$`, over time, `$t$`, in seconds is given by the equation `$b(t)=10000\frac{1}{t}$`.

When is the model not accurate? Assume that the solution was introduced at `$t=0$`.
questions.answer: If `$t < 1$`, the equation would tell you that the number of bacteria was increasing instead of decreasing.

questions.question_html:
Consider the function f(x)=\displaystyle{\frac{4x-3}{x+1}}.

a) State the equation of the vertical asymptote.

b) Determine the behaviour(s) of the function near its vertical asymptote.

c) State the equation of the horizontal asymptote.

d) Use a table of values to determine the end behaviours of the function near its horizontal asymptote.

e) Determine the domain and range.

f) Determine the positive and negative intervals.
questions.question:
Consider the function `$f(x)=\displaystyle{\frac{4x-3}{x+1}}$`.

**a)** State the equation of the vertical asymptote.

**b)** Determine the behaviour(s) of the function
near its vertical asymptote.

**c)** State the equation of the horizontal asymptote.

**d)** Use a table of values to determine the end behaviours of the
function near its horizontal asymptote.

**e)** Determine the domain and range.

**f)** Determine the positive and negative intervals.
questions.answer:
a) `$x = -1$`

b) As `$x \rightarrow -1$` from the left, `$y \rightarrow \infty$`. As `$x \rightarrow -1$` from the right, `$y \rightarrow -\infty$`.

c) `$y =4$`

d) As `$x \rightarrow \pm \infty$`, `$f(x)$` gets closer and closer to `$4$`.

e) `$D = \{x \in \mathbb{R} \mid x \neq -1\}$`

`$R = \{y \in \mathbb{R} \mid  y \neq 4\}$`

f) positive: `$(-\infty,-1)$` and `$\left(\dfrac{3}{4},-\infty \right)$`

negative: `$\left(-1,\dfrac{3}{4}\right)$`
questions.answer_html:
a) x = -1

b) As x \rightarrow -1 from the left, y \rightarrow \infty. As x \rightarrow -1 from the right, y \rightarrow -\infty.

c) y =4

d) As x \rightarrow \pm \infty, f(x) gets closer and closer to 4.

e) D = \{x \in \mathbb{R} \mid x \neq -1\}

R = \{y \in \mathbb{R} \mid y \neq 4\}

f) positive: (-\infty,-1) and \left(\dfrac{3}{4},-\infty \right)

negative: \left(-1,\dfrac{3}{4}\right)

  • increasing when x \epsilon (-\infty,2),
  • decreasing when x \epsilon (2,\infty)
questions.question:

of the form `$\displaystyle f(x)=\frac{1}{(ax+b)(cx+d)}$` that meets these conditions.
graph.



* vertical asymptotes at `$x=-2$` and `$x=6$`, 
* horizontal asymptote at `$y=0$`;

* increasing when `$x \epsilon (-\infty,2)$`, 
* decreasing when `$x \epsilon (2,\infty)$`

questions.question_html:
The function I(t)=\displaystyle{\frac{15t+25}{t}} gives the value of an investment, in thousands of dollars, over t years.

a) Choose a very small value of t (a value near zero). Calculate the value of the investment at this time. Do you think that the function is accurate at this time? Why or why not?

b) As time passes, what will the value of the investment approach?
questions.question:
The function `$I(t)=\displaystyle{\frac{15t+25}{t}}$` gives the value of an investment, in thousands of dollars, over `$t$` years.

a) Choose a very small value of `$t$` (a value near zero). Calculate the
value of the investment at this time. Do you think that the
function is accurate at this time? Why or why not?

b) As time passes, what will the value of the investment approach?
questions.answer:
a) The function is probably not accurate
at very small values of `$t$` because as `$t \rightarrow 0$` from the right, `$x \rightarrow \infty$`

b) `$\$15000$`
questions.answer_html:
a) The function is probably not accurate at very small values of t because as t \rightarrow 0 from the right, x \rightarrow \infty

b) \$15000

questions.question_html: An amount of chlorine is added to a swimming pool that contains pure water. The concentration of chlorine, c, in the pool at t hours is given by c(t)=\displaystyle{\frac{2t}{2+t}}, where c is measured in milligrams per litre. What happens to the concentration of chlorine in the pool during the 24 h period after the chlorine is added?
questions.question:
An amount of chlorine is added to a swimming pool that contains
pure water. The concentration of chlorine, `$c$`, in the pool at `$t$` hours is
given by `$c(t)=\displaystyle{\frac{2t}{2+t}}$`, where `$c$` is measured in milligrams per litre. What  happens to the concentration of chlorine in the pool during the
24 h period after the chlorine is added?
questions.answer:
The concentration increases over the
`$24$` h period and approaches approximately
`$1.89$` mg/L.
questions.answer_html: The concentration increases over the 24 h period and approaches approximately 1.89 mg/L.

questions.question_html: The Greek mathematician Pythagoras is credited with the discovery of the Golden Rectangle. In a Golden Rectangle, the length and width are related by the proportion \frac{l}{w} = \frac{w}{l - w}. A billboard with a length of 15 m is going to be built. What must its width be to form a Golden Rectangle?

questions.question_html: The Turtledove Chocolate factory has two chocolate machines. Machine A takes s minutes to fill a case with chocolates, and machine B takes s + 10 minutes to fill a case. questions.question: The Turtledove Chocolate factory has two chocolate machines. Machine A takes `$s$` minutes to fill a case with chocolates, and machine B takes `$s + 10$` minutes to fill a case. Working together, the two machines take 15 min to fill a case. Approximately how long does each machine take to fill a case?
questions.answer_html:
Machine A = 25.8 min

Machine B = 35.8 min

questions.question_html:
Three employees work at a shipping warehouse. Tom can fill an order in s minutes. Paco can fill an order in s -2 minutes. Carl can fill an order in s + 1 minutes. When Tom and Paco work together, they take about 1 minute and 20 seconds to fill an order. When Paco and Carl work together, they take about 1 minute and 30 seconds to fill an order.

a) How long does each person take to fill an order?

b) How long would all three of them, working together, take to fill an order?
questions.question:
Three employees work at a shipping warehouse. Tom can fill an order in `$s$` minutes. Paco can fill an order in `$s -2$` minutes. Carl can fill an order in `$s + 1$` minutes. When Tom and Paco work together, they take about `$1$` minute and `$20$` seconds to fill an order. When Paco and Carl work together, they take about `$1$` minute and `$30$` seconds to fill an order.

a) How long does each person take to fill an order?

b) How long would all three of them, working together, take to fill an order?
questions.answer:
a) Tom `$= 4$` min

Carl `$= 5$` min

Paco `$= 2$` min

b) `$6.4$` min
questions.answer_html:
a) Tom = 4 min

Carl = 5 min

Paco = 2 min

b) 6.4 min

questions.question:

**b)** What will happen to the concentration of pollutant over time?

questions.question_html: The equation f(t)=\displaystyle{\frac{5t}{t^2+3t+2}} models the bacteria count, in thousands, for a sample of tap water that is left to sit over time, t, in days. Will the bacteria count for the tap water sample ever exceed the bacteria count for the pond water? When? If no, explain why.

questions.question:
You are given `$\cos \theta = - \frac{5}{13}$`, where `$0 \leq \theta \leq 2\pi$`.

a) In which quadrant(s) could the terminal arm of `$\theta$` lie?

b) Determine all the possible trigonometric ratios for `$\theta$`.

c) State all the possible radian values of `$\theta$`, to the nearest hundredth.
questions.answer:
second or third quadrant

`$\sin \theta = \dfrac{12}{3} \text{ or } -\dfrac{12}{13},$`

`$\tan \theta = \dfrac{12}{5} \text{ or } -\dfrac{12}{5},$`

`$\sec \theta = -\dfrac{13}{5},$`

`$\csc \theta = \dfrac{13}{12} \text{ 
or } -\dfrac{13}{12},$`

`$\cot \theta = \dfrac{5}{12} \text{ or } -\dfrac{5}{12}$`
questions.answer_html:
second or third quadrant

\sin \theta = \dfrac{12}{3} \text{ or } -\dfrac{12}{13},

\tan \theta = \dfrac{12}{5} \text{ or } -\dfrac{12}{5},

\sec \theta = -\dfrac{13}{5},

\cot \theta = \dfrac{5}{12} \text{ or } -\dfrac{5}{12}

(b) maximum values

questions.answer:

Each person's blood pressure is different, but there is a range of blood pressure values that is considered healthy. The function P(t) = -20\cos{\displaystyle{\frac{5\pi}{3}}}t+100 models the blood pressure, p, in millimetres of mercury, at time t, in seconds, of a person at rest.

a) What is the period of the function? What does the period represent for an individual?
questions.question:
Each person's blood pressure is different, but there is a range of blood
pressure values that is considered healthy. The function `$P(t) = -20\cos{\displaystyle{\frac{5\pi}{3}}}t+100$` models the blood pressure, `$p$`, in
millimetres of mercury, at time `$t$`, in seconds, of a person at rest.

a) What is the period of the function? What does the period
represent for an individual?
questions.answer:
Period: `$\dfrac{6}{5}$`;

This represents the time between one beat of a person’s heart and the next beat.

questions.question_html:
Each person's blood pressure is different, but there is a range of blood pressure values that is considered healthy. The function P(t) = -20\cos{\displaystyle{\frac{5\pi}{3}}}t+100 models the blood pressure, p, in millimetres of mercury, at time t, in seconds, of a person at rest.

d) What is the range of the function? Explain the meaning of the range in terms of a person's blood pressure.
questions.question:
Each person's blood pressure is different, but there is a range of blood
pressure values that is considered healthy. The function `$P(t) = -20\cos{\displaystyle{\frac{5\pi}{3}}}t+100$` models the blood pressure, `$p$`, in
millimetres of mercury, at time `$t$`, in seconds, of a person at rest.

d) What is the range of the function? Explain the meaning of the
range in terms of a person's blood pressure.
questions.answer: The range for the function is between `$80$` and `$120$`. The range means the lowest blood pressure is `$80$` and the highest blood pressure is `$120$`.

questions.question_html:

questions.question:
A rung on a hamster wheel, with a radius of 25 cm, is travelling at a
constant speed. It makes one complete revolution in 3 s. The axle of
the hamster wheel is 27 cm above the ground.

b) Describe the transformations necessary to transform `$y = \cos{x}$` into the function you graphed in part a).

c) Write the equation that models this situation.
questions.answer:
b) * vertical stretch by a factor of `$25$`

* reflection in the `$x$`-axis

* vertical translation `$27$` units up

* horizontal compression by a factor of `$\dfrac{1}{\mid k \mid} = \dfrac{3}{2\pi}$`

c) `$y=-25\cos \left(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}x\right)+27$`
questions.answer_html:
b) * vertical stretch by a factor of 25

  • reflection in the x-axis

  • vertical translation 27 units up

  • horizontal compression by a factor of \dfrac{1}{\mid k \mid} = \dfrac{3}{2\pi}

c) y=-25\cos \left(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}x\right)+27

questions.question_html: The height of a patch on a bicycle tire above the ground, as a function of time, is modelled by one sinusoidal function. Which of the following characteristics do the two sinusoidal functions share: amplitude, period, equation of the axis?

questions.question_html: A person who was listening to a siren reported that the frequency of the sound fluctuated with time, measured in seconds. The minimum frequency that the person heard was 500 Hz, and the maximum frequency was 1000 Hz. The maximum frequency occurred at t = 0 and t = 15. The person also reported that, in 15, she heard the maximum frequency 6 times (including the times at t = 0 and t = 15). What is the equation of the cosine function that describes the frequency of this siren?

questions.question_html: A clock is hanging on a wall, with the centre of the clock 3 m above the floor. Both the minute hand and the second hand are 15 cm long. The hour hand is 8 cm long. For each hand, determine the equation of the cosine function that describes the distance of the tip of the hand above the floor as a function of time. Assume that the time, t, is in minutes and that the distance, D(t), is in centimetres. Also assume that t = 0 is midnight.
questions.question: A clock is hanging on a wall, with the centre of the clock 3 m above the floor. Both the minute hand and the second hand are 15 cm long. The hour hand is 8 cm long. For each hand, determine the equation of the cosine function that describes the distance of the tip of the hand above the floor as a function of time. Assume that the time, t, is in minutes and that the distance, `$D(t)$`, is in centimetres. Also assume that `$t = 0$` is midnight.
questions.answer:
minute hand:

`$D(t)=15\cos{\dfrac{\pi}{30}t}+300;$`

second hand:

`$D(t) = 15\cos{(2\pi t)}+300;$`

hour hand:

`$D(t)=8\cos{\left(\dfrac{\pi}{360}t\right)}+300$`
questions.answer_html:
minute hand:

D(t)=15\cos{\dfrac{\pi}{30}t}+300;

second hand:

D(t) = 15\cos{(2\pi t)}+300;

hour hand:

D(t)=8\cos{\left(\dfrac{\pi}{360}t\right)}+300

Consider the polynomial functions

\displaystyle f(x)=x^{2}-5 x+6 and \displaystyle g(x)=x-3 . Determine a) the zeros of \displaystyle f(x), g(x), \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} , and \displaystyle \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} b) the holes and asymptotes of \displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} and \displaystyle \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} , if any c) any \displaystyle x -coordinate(s) where the tangents of \displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} and \displaystyle f(x) are perpendicular, and the equation(s) of the tangent \displaystyle (s) at such coordinates
questions.question:
Consider the polynomial functions

`$\displaystyle f(x)=x^{2}-5 x+6 $` and `$\displaystyle g(x)=x-3 $`. Determine a) the zeros of `$\displaystyle f(x), g(x), \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $`, and `$\displaystyle \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} $` b) the holes and asymptotes of `$\displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $` and `$\displaystyle \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} $`, if any c) any `$\displaystyle x $`-coordinate(s) where the tangents of `$\displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $` and `$\displaystyle f(x) $` are perpendicular, and the equation(s) of the tangent `$\displaystyle (s) $` at such coordinates
questions.answer:
a) The zeros of `$\displaystyle f(x) $` are `$\displaystyle x=2 $` or `$\displaystyle x=3 . $` The zero of `$\displaystyle g(x) $` is `$\displaystyle x=3 . $` The zero of `$\displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $` is `$\displaystyle x=2 \cdot \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} $` does not have any zeros.

b) `$\displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} $` has a hole at `$\displaystyle x=3 $`; no asymptotes. `$\displaystyle \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} $` has an asymptote at `$\displaystyle x=2 $` and `$\displaystyle y=0 $`

c) `$\displaystyle x=1 ; \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}: y=x-2, \frac{g(x)}{f(x)}: y=-x $`
questions.answer_html:
a) The zeros of \displaystyle f(x) are \displaystyle x=2 or \displaystyle x=3 . The zero of \displaystyle g(x) is \displaystyle x=3 . The zero of \displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} is \displaystyle x=2 \cdot \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} does not have any zeros.

b) \displaystyle \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} has a hole at \displaystyle x=3 ; no asymptotes. \displaystyle \frac{g(x)}{f(x)} has an asymptote at \displaystyle x=2 and \displaystyle y=0

c) \displaystyle x=1 ; \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}: y=x-2, \frac{g(x)}{f(x)}: y=-x

questions.question_html:
a) Investigate the effect of various types of transformations (i.e., stretches/compressions, reflections, and translations) of \displaystyle y=\sin x on its zeros, maximum and minimum values, and instantaneous rates of change.

b) Repeat part a) for \displaystyle y=\cos x and \displaystyle y=\tan x .
questions.question:
a) Investigate the effect of various types of transformations (i.e., stretches/compressions, reflections, and translations) of `$\displaystyle y=\sin x $` on its zeros, maximum and minimum values, and instantaneous rates of change.

b) Repeat part a) for `$\displaystyle y=\cos x $` and `$\displaystyle y=\tan x . $`
questions.answer:
a) Vertical compressions and stretches do not affect location of zeros; maximum

and minimum values are multiplied

by the scale factor, but locations are

unchanged; instantaneous rates of

change are multiplied by the scale

factor.


Horizontal compressions and stretches

move locations of zeros, maximums,

and minimums toward or away from

the `$\displaystyle y $`-axis by the reciprocal of the scale factor; instantaneous rates of change are multiplied by the reciprocal of scale

factor.

Vertical translations change location of zeros or remove them; maximum and

minimum values are increased or

decreased by the amount of the

translation, but locations are

unchanged; instantaneous rates of

change are unchanged.

Horizontal translations move location

of zeros by the same amount as the

translation; maximum and minimum

values are unchanged, but locations are

moved by the same amount as the

translation; instantaneous rates of

change are unchanged, but locations are

moved by the same amount as the

translation.

For `$\displaystyle y=\cos x $`, the answer is the same as in part a), except that a horizontal

reflection does not affect instantaneous rates of change. For `$\displaystyle y=\tan x $`, the answer is also the same as in part a),

except that nothing affects the

maximum and minimum values, since

there are no maximum or minimum

values for `$\displaystyle y=\tan x . $`
questions.answer_html:
a) Vertical compressions and stretches do not affect location of zeros; maximum

and minimum values are multiplied

by the scale factor, but locations are

unchanged; instantaneous rates of

change are multiplied by the scale

factor.

Horizontal compressions and stretches

move locations of zeros, maximums,

and minimums toward or away from

the \displaystyle y -axis by the reciprocal of the scale factor; instantaneous rates of change are multiplied by the reciprocal of scale

factor.

Vertical translations change location of zeros or remove them; maximum and

minimum values are increased or

decreased by the amount of the

translation, but locations are

unchanged; instantaneous rates of

change are unchanged.

Horizontal translations move location

of zeros by the same amount as the

translation; maximum and minimum

values are unchanged, but locations are

moved by the same amount as the

translation; instantaneous rates of

change are unchanged, but locations are

moved by the same amount as the

translation.

For \displaystyle y=\cos x , the answer is the same as in part a), except that a horizontal

reflection does not affect instantaneous rates of change. For \displaystyle y=\tan x , the answer is also the same as in part a),

except that nothing affects the

maximum and minimum values, since

there are no maximum or minimum

values for \displaystyle y=\tan x .

What transformations are needed to transform \displaystyle y=\cos x into \displaystyle y=\cos \left(\frac{1}{3}(x+2 \pi)\right) ? a) horizontal compression by a factor of \displaystyle \frac{1}{3} , horizontal translation \displaystyle 2 \pi units left b) horizontal stretch by a factor of 3 , horizontal translation \displaystyle 2 \pi units left c) vertical compression by a factor of \displaystyle \frac{1}{3} , vertical translation 2 units up

d) horizontal stretch by a factor of 3 , horizontal translation \displaystyle 2 \pi units left

d) horizontal stretch by a factor of 3 , horizontal translation `$\displaystyle 2 \pi $` units left

questions.question_html: One blade of a wind turbine is at an angle of \displaystyle -\frac{\pi}{4} to the upward vertical at time \displaystyle t=0 , and rotates counterclockwise one revolution every 2 seconds. The tip of the blade varies between \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~m} and \displaystyle 41 \mathrm{~m} above the ground. Which equation is a model for the height, \displaystyle h , of the blade tip? a) \displaystyle \quad h=18 \cos \left(\pi t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)+23 b) \displaystyle \quad h=41 \cos \left(2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)-5 c) \displaystyle \quad h=18 \cos \left(\pi t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)-23 d) \displaystyle h=41 \cos \left(\pi\left(t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)-36
questions.question: One blade of a wind turbine is at an angle of `$\displaystyle -\frac{\pi}{4} $` to the upward vertical at time `$\displaystyle t=0 $`, and rotates counterclockwise one revolution every 2 seconds. The tip of the blade varies between `$\displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~m} $` and `$\displaystyle 41 \mathrm{~m} $` above the ground. Which equation is a model for the height, `$\displaystyle h $`, of the blade tip? a) `$\displaystyle \quad h=18 \cos \left(\pi t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)+23 $` b) `$\displaystyle \quad h=41 \cos \left(2\left(t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)-5 $` c) `$\displaystyle \quad h=18 \cos \left(\pi t-\frac{\pi}{4}\right)-23 $` d) `$\displaystyle h=41 \cos \left(\pi\left(t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\right)-36 $`

Over } \\ \text { which time interval is the average rate of change } \\ \text { in the blackfly population the greatest? } \\ \text { a) } 0 \leq t \leq 4 & \text { c) } 7 \leq t \leq 16 \\ \text { b) } 1 \leq t \leq 7 & \text { d) } 10 \leq t \leq 18\end{array}

questions.question_html:
An open top box is made by cutting corners out of a \displaystyle 50 \mathrm{~cm} by \displaystyle 40 \mathrm{~cm} piece of cardboard.

a) Determine a mathematical model that represents the volume of the box.

b) Determine the length of the sides of each square that must be cut that will result in a box with a volume of \displaystyle 6000 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} .

c) Determine the length of the sides of each square that must be cut that will result in a box with maximum volume.

d) Determine a range of sizes of the squares that can be cut from each corner that will result in a box with a volume of at least \displaystyle 1008 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} .
questions.question:
An open top box is made by cutting corners out of a `$\displaystyle 50 \mathrm{~cm} $` by `$\displaystyle 40 \mathrm{~cm} $` piece of cardboard.

a) Determine a mathematical model that represents the volume of the box.

b) Determine the length of the sides of each square that must be cut that will result in a box with a volume of `$\displaystyle 6000 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} $`.

c) Determine the length of the sides of each square that must be cut that will result in a box with maximum volume.

d) Determine a range of sizes of the squares that can be cut from each corner that will result in a box with a volume of at least `$\displaystyle 1008 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} $`.
questions.answer:
a) If `$\displaystyle x $` is the length in centimetres of a side of one of the corners that have been cut out, the volume of the box is `$\displaystyle (50-2 x)(40-2 x) \times \mathrm{cm}^{3} $`

b) `$\displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~cm} $` or `$\displaystyle 10 \mathrm{~cm} $`

c) `$\displaystyle x \doteq 7.4 \mathrm{~cm} $`


a) If `$\displaystyle x $` is the length in centimetres of a side of one of the corners that have been cut out, the volume of the box is `$\displaystyle (50-2 x)(40-2 x) \times \mathrm{cm}^{3} $`

b) `$\displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~cm} $` or `$\displaystyle 10 \mathrm{~cm} $`

c) `$\displaystyle x \doteq 7.4 \mathrm{~cm} $`
questions.answer_html:
a) If \displaystyle x is the length in centimetres of a side of one of the corners that have been cut out, the volume of the box is \displaystyle (50-2 x)(40-2 x) \times \mathrm{cm}^{3}

b) \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~cm} or \displaystyle 10 \mathrm{~cm}

c) \displaystyle x \doteq 7.4 \mathrm{~cm}

a) If \displaystyle x is the length in centimetres of a side of one of the corners that have been cut out, the volume of the box is \displaystyle (50-2 x)(40-2 x) \times \mathrm{cm}^{3}

b) \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~cm} or \displaystyle 10 \mathrm{~cm}

c) \displaystyle x \doteq 7.4 \mathrm{~cm}

questions.question:
Use the graph of `$y = \sin \theta$` to estimate the value(s) of `$\theta$` in the interval `$0\leq \theta \leq 2\pi$`.


`$
\displaystyle
\begin{array}{cccccc}
 &(a) & \sin \theta = 1		& (b) & \sin \theta = 0.5		& (c) &\sin \theta = 0 \\
  &(d) & \sin \theta = -1		&(e) & \sin \theta =- 0.5		& (f) &\sin \theta = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\\
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer_html:

b) \dfrac{3\pi}{2}

c) \dfrac{\pi}{6} or \dfrac{5\pi}{6}

d) \dfrac{7\pi}{6} or \dfrac{11\pi}{6}

e) 0, \pi, or 2\pi

f) \dfrac{\pi}{3} or \dfrac{2\pi}{3}

questions.question_html: Natasha is a marathon runner, and she likes to train on a 2\pi km stretch of rolling hills. The height, in kilometres, of the hills above sea level, relative to her home, can be modelled by the function h(d) = 4\cos^2d - 1, where d is the distance travelled in kilometres. At what intervals in the stretch of rolling hills is the height above sea level, relative to Natasha’s home, less than zero?
questions.question:
Natasha is a marathon runner, and she likes to train on a `$2\pi$` km stretch of rolling hills.  The height, in kilometres, of the hills above
sea level, relative to her home, can be modelled by the function `$h(d) = 4\cos^2d  - 1$`, where `$d$` is the distance travelled in kilometres. At what intervals in the stretch of rolling hills is the height above sea level, relative to Natasha’s home, less than zero?
questions.answer:
`$\dfrac{\pi}{3}$` km `$< d < \dfrac{2\pi}{3}$` km,

`$\dfrac{4\pi}{3}$` km `$< d < \dfrac{5\pi}{3}$` km
questions.answer_html:
\dfrac{\pi}{3} km < d < \dfrac{2\pi}{3} km,

\dfrac{4\pi}{3} km < d < \dfrac{5\pi}{3} km

questions.question_html:
(a) Solve the equation \sin^2x -\sqrt{2} \cos x = \cos^2x + \sqrt{2} \cos x + 2 for x in the interval 0\leq x\leq 2\pi

(b) Write a general solution for the equation in part a).
questions.question:
**(a)** Solve the equation `$\sin^2x -\sqrt{2} \cos x = \cos^2x + \sqrt{2} \cos x + 2$` for `$x$` in the interval `$0\leq x\leq 2\pi$`

(b) Write a general solution for the equation in part a).
questions.answer_html:
a) x = \dfrac{3\pi}{4} \text{ or } \dfrac{5\pi}{4}

b) x=\dfrac{3\pi}{4}+2n\pi \text{ or } \dfrac{5\pi}{4}+2n\pi, where n\in\mathbb{I}

questions.answer:
#279578

`$\displaystyle \begin{aligned} \angle S & =\left(A^{2}\right)^{3}-\left(B^{2}\right)^{3} \quad  \\ & =\left(A^{2}-B^{2}\right)\left(A^{4}+A^{2} B^{2}+B^{4}\right) \\ & =\left(\sec ^{2} x-\tan ^{2} x\right)\left(\sec ^{4} x+\sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x+\tan ^{4} x\right) \\ & =\left(\frac{1-\sin ^{2} x}{\cos ^{2} x}\right)\left(\sec ^{4} x+\sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x+\tan ^{4} x\right) \\ & \left.=1 \cdot\left((\sec ^{2} x-\tan ^{2}x\right)^{2}+3 \sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x\right) \\ & =1+3 \sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x=P S\end{aligned} $`
questions.answer_html: \displaystyle \begin{aligned} \angle S & =\left(A^{2}\right)^{3}-\left(B^{2}\right)^{3} \quad \\ & =\left(A^{2}-B^{2}\right)\left(A^{4}+A^{2} B^{2}+B^{4}\right) \\ & =\left(\sec ^{2} x-\tan ^{2} x\right)\left(\sec ^{4} x+\sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x+\tan ^{4} x\right) \\ & =\left(\frac{1-\sin ^{2} x}{\cos ^{2} x}\right)\left(\sec ^{4} x+\sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x+\tan ^{4} x\right) \\ & \left.=1 \cdot\left((\sec ^{2} x-\tan ^{2}x\right)^{2}+3 \sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x\right) \\ & =1+3 \sec ^{2} x \tan ^{2} x=P S\end{aligned}

questions.question_html:
Write the equation of each inverse function below in

i) exponential form

ii) logarithmic form

\displaystyle \begin{array}{llllll} &(a) & f(x) = 4^x &(c) & f(x) = (\frac{1}{3})^x\\ &&&&\\ &(c) & f(x) = 8^x &(d) & f(x) = (\frac{1}{5})^x\\ \end{array}
questions.question:
Write the equation of each inverse function below in 

**i)** exponential form

**ii)** logarithmic form

`$
\displaystyle
\begin{array}{llllll}
&(a) & f(x) = 4^x    &(c) & f(x) = (\frac{1}{3})^x\\
&&&&\\
&(c) & f(x) = 8^x    &(d) & f(x) = (\frac{1}{5})^x\\
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer_html:
a)

  • i) x=4^y
  • ii) \log_4{x}=y

b)

  • i) x=8^y
  • ii) \log_8{x}=y

c)

  • i) x=\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^y
  • ii) \log_{\frac{1}{3}}{x}=y

d)

  • i) x=\left(\dfrac{1}{5}\right)^y
  • ii) \log_{\frac{1}{5}}{x}=y

Write the equation of the inverse of each exponential function below in logarithmic form.

\displaystyle \begin{array}{llllll} &(a) & f(x) = 3^x &(c) & f(x) = (\frac{1}{4})^x\\ &&&&\\ &(c) & f(x) = 10^x &(d) & f(x) = m^x\\ \end{array}
questions.question:
Write the equation of the inverse of each exponential function below in logarithmic form.

`$
\displaystyle
\begin{array}{llllll}
&(a) & f(x) = 3^x    &(c) & f(x) = (\frac{1}{4})^x\\
&&&&\\
&(c) & f(x) = 10^x    &(d) & f(x) = m^x\\
\end{array}
$`
questions.answer_html:
a) x=3^y

b) x=10^y

c) x=\left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)^y

d) x=m^y

i) g(x)=-4\log_{10}x+5
questions.question:
Let `$f(x)=\log_{10}x$`. For each function `$g(x)$`

**(a)** What transformations must be applied to `$f$` to produce the graph of `$g$`?

**(b)** Which coordinates of the points on `$g$` are images of the points `$(1,0)$` and `$(10,1)$` on the graph of `$f$`?

**(c)** What is the equation of the asymptote?

**(d)** What is the domain and range?

*i)* `$g(x)=-4\log_{10}x+5$`
questions.answer:
a) 

* reflection in the `$x$`-axis

* vertical stretch by a factor of `$4$`

* translation `$5$` units up
 
b) `$(1,5),(10,1)$`

c) vertical asymptote: `$x=0$`

d) `$D = \{x\in\mathbb{R}\mid x > 0\},$`

`$R=\{y\in\mathbb{R}\}$`
questions.answer_html:
a)

  • reflection in the x-axis

  • vertical stretch by a factor of 4

  • translation 5 units up

b) (1,5),(10,1)

c) vertical asymptote: x=0

d) D = \{x\in\mathbb{R}\mid x > 0\},

R=\{y\in\mathbb{R}\}

questions.answer:
* `$g(x)$` is the same as `$f(x)$` but horizontally translated `$4$` units to the left.

* `$h(x)$` is the same as `$f(x)$` but vertically translated `$4$` units up
questions.answer_html:
• g(x) is the same as f(x) but horizontally translated 4 units to the left.

  • h(x) is the same as f(x) but vertically translated 4 units up

questions.question_html: The astronomer Johannes Kepler (1571~1630) determined that the time, D, in days, for a planet to revolve around the Sun is related to the planet's average distance from the Sun, k, in millions of kilometres. This relation is defined by the equation \displaystyle{\log D=\frac{3}{2}\log k-0.7} Verify that Kepler's equation gives a good approximation of the time it takes for Earth to revolve around the Sun, if Earth is about 150 000 000 km from the Sun.

questions.question_html:
Half-life is the time it takes for half of a sample of a radioactive element to decay. The function \displaystyle{M(t)=P\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{t}{h}}} can be used to calculate the mass remaining if the half-life is h and the initial mass is P. The half-life of radium is 1620 years.

  • If a laboratory has 5 g of radium, how much will there be in 150 years?
questions.question:
Half-life is the time it takes for half of a sample of a radioactive element to decay. The function `$\displaystyle{M(t)=P\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{t}{h}}}$` can be used to calculate the mass remaining if the half-life is `$h$` and the initial mass is `$P$`. The half-life of radium is 1620 years.

* If a laboratory has 5 g of radium, how much will there be in 150 years?

questions.question_html:
Half-life is the time it takes for half of a sample of a radioactive element to decay. The function \displaystyle{M(t)=P\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{t}{h}}} can be used to calculate the mass remaining if the half-life is h and the initial mass is P. The half-life of radium is 1620 years.

b) How many years will it take until the laboratory has only 4 g of radium?

questions.question_html: Write y = \log_2(4x), y = \log_2(8x), and y= \log_2(\frac{x}{2}) with respect to y =\log_2x.
questions.question: Write `$y = \log_2(4x), y = \log_2(8x)$`, and `$y= \log_2(\frac{x}{2})$`  with respect to `$y  =\log_2x$`.
questions.answer_html:
• y = \log_2(4x)=2+\log_2x
  • y = \log_2(8x)=3+\log_2x
  • y= \log_2(\frac{x}{2})=\log_2x - 1

questions.question_html:
The formula to calculate the mass, M(t), remaining from an original sample of radioactive material with mass P, is determined using the formula M(t) = P(\frac{1}{2})^{\frac{t}{h}}, where t is time and h is the half-life of the substance. The half-life of a radioactive substance is 8 h. How long will it take for a 300 g sample to decay to each mass?

  • 200 g
questions.question:
The formula to calculate the mass, `$M(t)$`, remaining from an original sample of radioactive material with mass `$P$`, is determined using the  formula `$M(t) = P(\frac{1}{2})^{\frac{t}{h}}$`, where `$t$` is time and `$h$` is the half-life of the substance. The half-life of a radioactive substance is 8 h. How long will it take for a 300 g sample to decay to each mass?

* 200  g

questions.question_html:
A plastic sun visor allows light to pass through but reduces the intensity of the light. The intensity is reduced by 5% if the plastic is 1 mm thick. Each additional millimetre of thickness reduces the intensity by another 5%.

a) Use an equation to model the relation between the thickness of the plastic and the intensity of the light.

b) How thick is a piece of plastic that reduces the intensity of the light to 60%?
questions.question:
A plastic sun visor allows light to pass through but reduces the intensity of the light. The intensity is reduced by 5% if the plastic is 1 mm thick. Each additional millimetre of thickness reduces the intensity by another 5%.


a) Use an equation to model the relation between the thickness
of the plastic and the intensity of the light.

b) How thick is a piece of plastic that reduces the intensity
of the light to 60%?

`$\displaystyle y=a \cdot b^{x}+c \quad b=3-1.525 $`

`$\displaystyle 3=a+c- $` (1.) `$\displaystyle \quad 76.9=a \cdot b^{4}+c $` (3) `$\displaystyle =1.475 $`

`$\displaystyle 15 \cdot 2=a \cdot b^{2}+c $` -

`$\displaystyle 12.2=a b^{2}-a \quad 73.9=a b^{4}-a $`

`$\displaystyle 12.2=a\left(b^{2}-1\right) $`-4) `$\displaystyle 73.9=a\left(b^{4}-1\right)-(5) $`

(5) `$\displaystyle \frac{73 \cdot)}{12 \cdot 2}=\frac{a\left(b^{4}-1\right)}{a f\left(b^{2}-1\right)}=\frac{\left(b^{2}-1\right)\left(b^{2}+1\right)}{b^{2}-1} $`

`$\displaystyle \frac{73.9}{12.2}=b^{2}+1 $`

`$\displaystyle 6.057=b^{2}+y $`

`$\displaystyle 5.057=b^{2} $`

`$\displaystyle b=(\sqrt{5.057} $`

\displaystyle y=a \cdot 3^{x}+b \quad 15 \cdot 2=a \cdot 3^{2}+b

\displaystyle 12.2=8 a

\displaystyle y=1.525 \times 3^{x}+1.475 . \quad a=\frac{122^{2}}{8}=1.525

\displaystyle y=a \cdot b^{x}+c \quad b=3-1.525

\displaystyle 3=a+c- (1.) \displaystyle \quad 76.9=a \cdot b^{4}+c (3) \displaystyle =1.475

\displaystyle 15 \cdot 2=a \cdot b^{2}+c -

\displaystyle 12.2=a b^{2}-a \quad 73.9=a b^{4}-a

\displaystyle 12.2=a\left(b^{2}-1\right) -4) \displaystyle 73.9=a\left(b^{4}-1\right)-(5)

(5) \displaystyle \frac{73 \cdot)}{12 \cdot 2}=\frac{a\left(b^{4}-1\right)}{a f\left(b^{2}-1\right)}=\frac{\left(b^{2}-1\right)\left(b^{2}+1\right)}{b^{2}-1}

\displaystyle \frac{73.9}{12.2}=b^{2}+1

\displaystyle 6.057=b^{2}+y

\displaystyle 5.057=b^{2}

questions.question_html:
The function \displaystyle{P(t)=5000-1000\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{6}t\right)} which models the deer population in a provincial park. A disease in the deer population has caused it to decline. Biologists have discovered that the deer population is decreasing by 25 deer each month.

a) Assuming that this pattern continues, determine the new function that will model the deer population over time and discuss its characteristics.

b) Estimate when the deer population in this park will be extinct.
questions.question:
The function `$\displaystyle{P(t)=5000-1000\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{6}t\right)}$` which models the deer population in a provincial park. A disease in the deer population has caused it to decline. Biologists have discovered that the deer population is decreasing by 25 deer each month.

**a)** Assuming that this pattern continues, determine the new function that will model the deer population over time and discuss its characteristics.

**b)** Estimate when the deer population in this park will be extinct.

questions.question_html: When the driver of a vehicle observes an obstacle in the vehicle’s path, the driver reacts to apply the brakes and bring the vehicle to a complete stop. The distance that the vehicle travels while coming to a stop is a combination of the reaction distance, r, in metres, given by r(x)=0.21x, and the braking distance, b also in metres, given by b(x)=0.006x^2. The speed of the vehicle is x km/h. Determine the stopping distance of the vehicle as a function of its speed, and calculate the stopping distance if the vehicle is travelling at 90 km/h.
questions.question: When the driver of a vehicle observes an obstacle in the vehicle’s path, the driver reacts to apply the brakes and bring the vehicle to a complete stop. questions.question_html: Determine a sine function, \displaystyle f , and a cosine function, \displaystyle g , such that \displaystyle y=\sqrt{2} \sin (\pi(x-2.25)) can be written in the form of \displaystyle f-g .
questions.question: Determine a sine function, `$\displaystyle f $`, and a cosine function, `$\displaystyle g $`, such that `$\displaystyle y=\sqrt{2} \sin (\pi(x-2.25)) $` can be written in the form of `$\displaystyle f-g $`.
questions.answer:
#14056

`$\displaystyle y=\sqrt{2} \sin (\pi(x-2.25)) $` can be written in the form

`$\displaystyle \begin{array}{l}
=\sqrt{2} \sin (\pi x-2.25 \pi) \\
=\sqrt{2}[\sin \pi \times \cos 2.25 \pi /-\cos \pi \times \sin 2.25 \pi] \\
\end{array} $`
questions.answer_html:
\displaystyle y=\sqrt{2} \sin (\pi(x-2.25)) can be written in the form

\displaystyle \begin{array}{l} =\sqrt{2} \sin (\pi x-2.25 \pi) \\ =\sqrt{2}[\sin \pi \times \cos 2.25 \pi /-\cos \pi \times \sin 2.25 \pi] \\ \end{array}

questions.question_html:
An airplane passes directly over a radar station at time t=0. The plane maintains an altitude of 4 km and is flying at a speed of 560 km/h. Let d represent the distance from the radar station to the plane, and let s represent the horizontal distance travelled by the plane since it passed over the radar station.

a) Express d as a function of s, and s as a function of t.

b) Use composition to express the distance between the plane and the radar station as a function of time.
questions.question:
An airplane passes directly over a radar station at time `$t=0$`. The plane maintains an altitude of 4 km and is flying at a speed of 560 km/h. Let `$d$` represent the distance from the radar station to the plane, and let `$s$` represent the horizontal distance travelled by the plane since it passed over the radar station.

**a)** Express `$d$` as a function of `$s$`, and `$s$` as a function of `$t$`.

**b)** Use composition to express the distance between the plane and the radar station as a function of time.

#2457
questions.answer_html:
a) d(s) = \sqrt{16-s^2}

s(t) = 560t

b) d(t) = \sqrt{16-(560t)^2}

questions.question_html: In a vehicle test lab, the speed of a car, v kilometres per hour, at a time of t hours is represented by v(t)=40+3t+t^2. The rate of gasoline consumption of the car, c litres per kilometre, at a speed of v kilometres per hour is represented by \displaystyle{c(v)=\left(\frac{v}{500}-0.1\right)^2+0.15}. Determine algebraically c(v(t)), the rate of gasoline consumption as a function of time. Determine, using technology, the time when the car is running most economically during a 4 h simulation.
questions.question: In a vehicle test lab, the speed of a car, `$v$` kilometres per hour, at a time of `$t$` hours is represented by `$v(t)=40+3t+t^2$`. The rate of gasoline consumption of the car, `$c$` litres per kilometre, at a speed of `$v$` kilometres per hour is represented by `$\displaystyle{c(v)=\left(\frac{v}{500}-0.1\right)^2+0.15}$`. Determine algebraically `$c(v(t))$`, the rate of gasoline consumption as a function of time. Determine, using technology, the time when the car is running most economically during a 4 h simulation.

questions.question_html:
In each case, functions f and g are defined for x\in\mathbb{R}. For each pair of functions, determine the expression and the domain of f(g(x)) and g(f(x)). Graph each result.

f(x) = 2x^3-3x^2+x-1,g(x)=2x-1
questions.question:
In each case, functions `$f$` and `$g$` are defined for `$x\in\mathbb{R}$`. For each pair of functions, determine the expression and the domain of `$f(g(x))$` and `$g(f(x))$`. Graph each result.


`$f(x) = 2x^3-3x^2+x-1,g(x)=2x-1$`
questions.answer_html:
f\circ g (x) = 2(2x -1)^3-3(2x -1)^2+(2x -1) -1

g\circ f(x) = 2(2x^3-3x^2 + x - 1) -1

D_{f\circ g} = \{x\in \mathbb{R}\}

D_{g\circ f} = \{x\in \mathbb{R}\}

questions.question_html:
An above-ground swimming pool in the shape of a cylinder, with diameter \displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~m} , is filled at a constant rate to a depth of \displaystyle 1 \mathrm{~m} . It takes \displaystyle 4 \mathrm{~h} to fill the pool with a hose.

a) Make a graph showing volume of water in the pool as a function of time.

b) Determine the equation of a mathematical model for volume as a function of time.

c) When will the volume of the water be \displaystyle 8 \mathrm{~m}^{3} ?
questions.question:
An above-ground swimming pool in the shape of a cylinder, with diameter `$\displaystyle 5 \mathrm{~m} $`, is filled at a constant rate to a depth of `$\displaystyle 1 \mathrm{~m} $`. It takes `$\displaystyle 4 \mathrm{~h} $` to fill the pool with a hose.

a) Make a graph showing volume of water in the pool as a function of time.

b) Determine the equation of a mathematical model for volume as a function of time.

c) When will the volume of the water be `$\displaystyle 8 \mathrm{~m}^{3} $` ?
