questions.question_html:
After being filled, the swimming pool in question 1 is accidentally punctured at the bottom and water leaks out. The volume of the pool reaches zero in \displaystyle 8 \mathrm{~h} . The volume of water remaining at time \displaystyle t follows a quadratic model, with the minimum point (vertex) at the time when the last of the water drains out.

a) Make a graph showing the volume of water in the pool versus time.

b) Find the equation for the quadratic model.

c) Use the model to predict the volume of water at the \displaystyle 2 \mathrm{~h} mark.

d) What is the average rate of change in the volume of the water during the first \displaystyle 2 \mathrm{~h} ?

e) How does the rate of change in volume vary as time elapses?

questions.question_html:
A lake in Northern Ontario has recovered from an acid spill that killed all of its trout. A restocking program puts 800 trout in the lake. Ten years later, the population is estimated to be 6000 . The carrying capacity of the lake is believed to be 8000 .

a) Make a graph to show the given information. Extend the time scale to 20 years.

b) Determine the parameters for a logistic model of the form \displaystyle P(t)=\frac{c}{1+a(b)^{t}} to model the growth of the trout population, and graph the function for \displaystyle t \in[0,20] .

c) Use the model to estimate the number of trout that were in the lake four years after restocking.

d) Use the model to estimate the average rate of change in the number of trout over the first four years of the restocking program.
questions.question:
A lake in Northern Ontario has recovered from an acid spill that killed all of its trout. A restocking program puts 800 trout in the lake. Ten years later, the population is estimated to be 6000 . The carrying capacity of the lake is believed to be 8000 .

a) Make a graph to show the given information. Extend the time scale to 20 years.

b) Determine the parameters for a logistic model of the form `$\displaystyle P(t)=\frac{c}{1+a(b)^{t}} $` to model the growth of the trout population, and graph the function for `$\displaystyle t \in[0,20] $`.

c) Use the model to estimate the number of trout that were in the lake four years after restocking.

d) Use the model to estimate the average rate of change in the number of trout over the first four years of the restocking program.

questions.question_html:
Consider again the population of trout in question 4. Another possible model for the trout situation is a transformed exponential function of the form \displaystyle P(t)=c-a(b)^{t} . A graph of this type of model, \displaystyle y=P(t) , is shown below.

a) What feature of the graph does the parameter \displaystyle c represent? What is the value of \displaystyle c for the trout population?

b) Determine the values of \displaystyle a and \displaystyle b by substituting the two known ordered pairs.

c) Graph this exponential model of the trout population for \displaystyle t \in[0,20] .

d) Use the model to estimate the number of trout that were in the lake four years after restocking.

e) Use the model to estimate the average rate of change in the number of trout over the first four years of the restocking program.
questions.question:
Consider again the population of trout in question 4. Another possible model for the trout situation is a transformed exponential function of the form `$\displaystyle P(t)=c-a(b)^{t} $`. A graph of this type of model, `$\displaystyle y=P(t) $`, is shown below.
#259499
a) What feature of the graph does the parameter `$\displaystyle c $` represent? What is the value of `$\displaystyle c $` for the trout population?

b) Determine the values of `$\displaystyle a $` and `$\displaystyle b $` by substituting the two known ordered pairs.

c) Graph this exponential model of the trout population for `$\displaystyle t \in[0,20] $`.

d) Use the model to estimate the number of trout that were in the lake four years after restocking.

e) Use the model to estimate the average rate of change in the number of trout over the first four years of the restocking program.

questions.question_html:
The following table shows the velocity of air, in litres per second, of a typical person's breathing while at rest. \displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|} \hline Time (s) & 0 & 0.25 & 0.50 & 0.75 & 1.00 & 1.25 & 1.50 & 1.75 & 2.00 & 2.25 & 2.50 & 2.75 & 3.00 \\ \hline Velocity (L/s) & 0 & 0.22 & 0.45 & 0.61 & 0.75 & 0.82 & 0.85 & 0.83 & 0.74 & 0.61 & 0.43 & 0.23 & 0 \\ \hline \end{array} a) Graph the data, and determine an equation that models the situation.

b) Use a graphing calculator to draw a scatter plot of the data. Enter your equation into the equation editor, and graph. Comment on the closeness of fit between the scatter plot and the graph.

c) At \displaystyle t=6 , what is the velocity of a typical person's breathing?

d) Estimate when the rate of change in the velocity of a person's breathing is the smallest during the first \displaystyle 3 \mathrm{~s} .

e) What is the significance of the value you found in part d)?

f) Estimate when the rate of change in the velocity of a person's breathing is the greatest during the first \displaystyle 3 \mathrm{~s} .

\hline Time (s) & 0 &  0.25  &  0.50  &  0.75  &  1.00  &  1.25  &  1.50  &  1.75  &  2.00  &  2.25  &  2.50  &  2.75  &  3.00  \\
\hline Velocity (L/s) & 0 &  0.22  &  0.45  &  0.61  &  0.75  &  0.82  &  0.85  &  0.83  &  0.74  &  0.61  &  0.43  &  0.23  & 0 \\

questions.question_html:
The following table shows the average number of monthly hours of sunshine for Toronto. \displaystyle \begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline Month & \mathrm{J} & \mathrm{F} & \mathrm{M} & \mathrm{A} & \mathrm{M} & \mathrm{J} & \mathrm{J} & \mathrm{A} & \mathrm{S} & \mathrm{O} & \mathrm{N} & \mathrm{D} \\ \hline Average Monthly Sunshine (h) & 95.5 & 112.6 & 150.5 & 187.7 & 229.7 & 254.9 & 278.0 & 244.0 & 184.7 & 145.7 & 82.3 & 72.6 \\ \hline \end{array} Source: Environment Canada

a) Create a scatter plot of the number of hours of sunshine versus time, where \displaystyle t=1 represents January, \displaystyle t=2 represents February, and so on.

b) Draw the curve of best fit.

c) Determine a function that models this situation.

d) When will the number of monthly hours of sunshine be at a maximum according to the function? When will it be a minimum according to the function?

e) Discuss how well the model fits the data.
questions.question:
The following table shows the average number of monthly hours of sunshine for Toronto.
`$\displaystyle
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Month &  \mathrm{J}  &  \mathrm{F}  &  \mathrm{M}  &  \mathrm{A}  &  \mathrm{M}  &  \mathrm{J}  &  \mathrm{J}  &  \mathrm{A}  &  \mathrm{S}  &  \mathrm{O}  &  \mathrm{N}  &  \mathrm{D}  \\
\hline Average Monthly Sunshine (h) &  95.5  &  112.6  &  150.5  &  187.7  &  229.7  &  254.9  &  278.0  &  244.0  &  184.7  &  145.7  &  82.3  &  72.6  \\
\hline
\end{array}
$`Source: Environment Canada

a) Create a scatter plot of the number of hours of sunshine versus time, where `$\displaystyle t=1 $` represents January, `$\displaystyle t=2 $` represents February, and so on.

b) Draw the curve of best fit.

c) Determine a function that models this situation.

d) When will the number of monthly hours of sunshine be at a maximum according to the function? When will it be a minimum according to the function?

e) Discuss how well the model fits the data.

questions.question_html:

From 1951 to 2006 , each period is a five-year interval.\displaystyle \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|} \hline & Census Population at the End of a Period (in thousands) & Period & Census Population at the End of a Period (in thousands) \\ \hline 1851-1861 & 3230 & 1951-1956 & 16081 \\ \hline 1861-1871 & 3689 & 1956-1961 & 18238 \\ \hline 1871-1881 & 4325 & 1961-1966 & 20015 \\ \hline 1881-1891 & 4833 & 1966-1971 & 21568 \\ \hline 1891-1901 & 5371 & 1971-1976 & 23450 \\ \hline 1901-1911 & 7207 & 1976-1981 & 24820 \\ \hline 1911-1921 & 8788 & 1981-1986 & 26101 \\ \hline 1921-1931 & 10377 & 1986-1991 & 28031 \\ \hline 1931-1941 & 11507 & 1991-1996 & 29672 \\ \hline 1941-1951 & 13648 & 1996-2001 & 30755 \\ \hline & & 2001-2006 & 31613 \\ \hline \end{array} Source: Statistics Canada, Demography Division

a) Use technology to investigate polynomial and exponential models for the relationship of the population and years since 1861 . Describe how well each model fits the data.

b) Use each model to estimate Canada's population in \displaystyle 2016 .

d) Use the model you chose in part c) to estimate the rate at which Canada's population was increasing in \displaystyle 2000 .

questions.question_html:
A franchise owner operates two coffee shops. The sales, \displaystyle S_{1} , in thousands of dollars, for shop 1 are represented by \displaystyle S_{1}(t)=700-1.4 t^{2} , where \displaystyle t=0 corresponds to the year 2000 . Similarly, the sales for shop 2 are represented by \displaystyle S_{2}(t)=t^{3}+3 t^{2}+500 .

a) Which shop is showing an increase in sales after the year 2000 ?

b) Determine a function that represents the total sales for the two coffee shops.

c) What are the expected total sales for the year 2006 ?

d) If sales continue according to the individual functions, what would you recommend that the owner do? Explain.

questions.question_html:
Let \displaystyle P represent the size of the frog population in a marsh at time \displaystyle t , in years. At \displaystyle t=0 , a species of frog is released into a marsh. When \displaystyle t=5 , biologists estimate that there are 2000 frogs in the marsh. Two years later, the biologists estimate that there are 3200 frogs.

a) Find a formula for \displaystyle P=f(t) , assuming linear growth. Interpret the slope and the \displaystyle P -intercept of your formula in terms of the frog population.

b) Find a formula for \displaystyle P=g(t) , assuming exponential growth. Interpret the parameters of your formula in terms of the frog population.
questions.question:

a) Find a formula for `$\displaystyle P=f(t) $`, assuming linear growth. Interpret the slope and the `$\displaystyle P $`-intercept of your formula in terms of the frog population.

b) Find a formula for `$\displaystyle P=g(t) $`, assuming exponential growth. Interpret the parameters of your formula in terms of the frog population.

questions.question_html:
A country projects that the average amount of money, in dollars, that it will collect in taxes from each taxpayer over the next 50 years can be modelled by the function \displaystyle A(t)=2850+200 t , where \displaystyle t is the number of years from now. It also projects that the number of taxpayers over the next 50 years can be modelled by the function \displaystyle C(t)=15000000(1.01)^{t}

a) Write the function that represents the amount of money, in dollars, that the country expects to collect in taxes over the next 50 years.

b) Graph the function you wrote in part a).

c) How much does the country expect to collect in taxes 26 years from now?
